 Staff Appraisal Report I 1. EDUCATION ISSUES AND STRATEGY A. BACKGROUND AND INTRODUCTION 1.1 Over the last 25 years, the Government of Indonesia has demonstrated a strong commitment to education and as a result, Indonesia has achieved one of the best rates of educational transition in the world. The Government-led enrollment drive and substantial school building program in the 1970s sharply increased primary school enrollment. The gross enrollment rate stood at 75 percent in the early 1970s but had increased to about 90 percent by the end of that decade. By the mid-1980s, gross enrollment rates exceeded 100 percent and by 1994/95 had reached 112 percent. The effort is not complete because of quality concerns and the need to increase retention rates, but the achievements at the primary level have been substantial in this diverse and far-flung archipelago. (Annexes 1-6 provide basic data on the educational structure and administration in Indonesia.) 1.2 The Government of Indonesia (GOI) is looking to future needs, and has reiterated its commitment to a proactive program in the future with expansion of junior secondary education as a priority. While maintaining its commitment to primary education, the Government is aiming for universal basic education (years 1-9) by 2008/09, to meet the human resource requirements for transforming the economy from one based on natural resources to one based more on industry and technology. 1.3 The decision to expand junior secondary education participation as rapidly as feasible is justified for several reasons (see Annex 7). First, expansion appears to be a precondition for the rapid growth of the Indonesian economy in the medium term. Recent research on the development of East Asian economies indicates that with the achievement of near universal primary education, secondary (junior and senior) education has had a strong impact on economic growth. Secondary education plays the role of providing educated entrants to the labor force, enhancing the trainability of workers, and providing qualified inputs into higher levels of education. 1.4 In this regard, the Indonesian economy and labor market are in the midst of a structural transformation. Since 1990, there has been a marked slow-down in employment creation in agriculture and an acceleration in the rate of growth of job creation in manufacturing, construction, transport and communication. After a period of wage stagnation in the 1980s, there are strong indications of rising real wage rates throughout the country and an absolute decline of employment in agriculture. If sustained nationally for a decade or so, these trends imply the absorption of remaining pockets of surplus labor, and as happened in other NICs, the transformation from an agrarian economy to one relying on the education and productivity of its workers. Social rates of return to education computed from 1986-92 indicate that returns to junior secondary education are the highest among the education subsectors.
 2 Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project 1.5 The second justification for significant Government attention to junior secondary education is that the number of school places is still limited relative to demand, despite substantial outlays by parents and a significant private sector response. This inadequacy is evident from continued strong demand for generally more costly and often lower quality private education, large numbers of unsuccessful applicants to schools, the prevalence of double shifts and large classes in schools, and the use of libraries and laboratories for classroom teaching. 1.6 A third rationale for Government intervention is to assist in removing barriers of cost and isolation that keep many of the rural poor out of school. In rural Java, for example, total expen- diture per junior secondary student is equivalent to approximately 86 percent of per capita household expenditure for households of the lowest quintile. Junior secondary education is therefore beyond the reach of many of the poor and near poor. The opportunity costs of keeping children in school exacerbate the problem. Expansion of junior secondary education in the remote rural areas -- which will be the main areas of focus because of their very low enrollment rates -- will be of direct benefit to the poor, especially girls who are sometimes disadvantaged in these areas. 1.7 A fourth rationale relates to likely externalities associated with investments in secondary education. Research from other countries has pointed to externalities such as reduced fertility and child mortality and improved nutritional status that correlate with female secondary education. For Indonesia, survey results indicate that a mother's education is an important determinant of prenatal care utilization: more than 90 percent of women with junior secondary education use prenatal care, in contrast to only 75 percent of women with some primary education. Furthermore, analysis of nutritional status in Indonesia finds a strong effect of maternal education on children's nutritional status: for women with between zero and five years of education, an additional year of education has no impact on the child's nutritional status, while among women with six to twelve years of education (or more), an additional year of education improves nutritional status significantly. 1.8 The role of the Government would therefore be to (a) help expand the number of school places through a combination of direct investment and measures to stimulate further private sector/community participation in the provision of school places, and (b) ensure that the poor are given increased opportunity to participate in the expansion process. Sector Financing Plan 1.9 Achieving universal nine-year basic education will require significant additional public resources to be directed to the education sector overall and to basic education in particular. Estimates of the total costs of the junior secondary expansion program come to approximately $7.6 billion to be phased out over a 15-year period (see Annex 7 for details). The cost estimates assume that the private sector will maintain its share of total enrollment of about 40 percent. During the next ten years of expansion, the budgetary shortfall is estimated at an average $120 million per annum. This is over and above additional resources generated by a 6 percent p.a. growth of the budget. This implies that the budgetary allocation to junior secondary education would need to increase from the current 13 percent of the education budget to approximately 16 percent in the next few years. Overall, Indonesia would need to increase its allocation to

In its most recent budget allocations (1996/97) the education sector budget was increased by 20 percent, one of the highest increases amongst all sectors. The budget for junior secondary education saw a 24 percent rise over last year's budget allocation. GOI is also requesting help from donors to close the financing gap. These efforts include proposed projects in junior secondary education in Indonesia for which World Bank assistance will be sought over the next four to five fiscal years. The Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project covers four of the country's 27 provinces: (a) Central Java (Jawa Tengah), (b) Central Kalimantan (Kalimantan Tengah), (c) West Kalimantan (Kalimantan Barat), and (d) Yogyakarta (D.I. Yogyakarta). Other projects currently under preparation are the East Java and East Nusa Tenggara Junior Secondary Education Project and the Sumatra Junior Secondary Education Project. The Secondary School Teacher Development Project (Loan 3979-IND) and the Book and Reading Development Project (Loan 3887-IND) will complement these efforts, as well as future basic and secondary education operations in other provinces. To promote efficiency and equity in the use of resources, the Government has recognized that educational development among and within the provinces must be balanced and appropriate to local conditions, meet an acceptable standard of quality, and take advantage of lessons learned within and outside the country. Structure of the Education System 1.12 The education system in Indonesia consists of a six-year primary school cycle, junior and senior secondary school cycles of three years each, and a postsecondary system ranging from one to six years. Primary education is largely the domain of Government: nearly five out of six pupils are enrolled in public schools. Private schooling plays a much greater role in secondary education. Private schools account for 41 percent of enrollment in junior secondary education and 54 percent in senior secondary. Junior secondary education is provided through 8,712 public and 10,279 private general junior secondary schools (SMP) and a remaining 300 vocational schools that emphasize either technical or home economics subjects, all of which are administered by the Ministry of Education and Culture (MOEC). The Ministry of Religious Affairs administers the 582 public and 7,547 private Muslim schools (Madrasahs, or MTs) at the junior secondary level. At the senior secondary level, 3,241 public and 10,380 private schools enroll a total of 4.2 million students, for a gross enrollment rate of 34 percent. Education statistics are found in Annex 8. 1.13 When a private junior secondary school is established, it is classified as "listed" and is evaluated after graduating its first students. Private schools can advance in accreditation from "registered" to "recognized" and finally to the status of "equivalent" to public schools. Most equivalent schools are owned and operated by religious organizations or large enterprises. Registered and recognized schools are in general owned and operated by teachers' associations and other nonprofit organizations (yayasans), although some are owned by religious organizations or small communities. Most listed schools are owned and operated by small rural communities that do not have a public school nearby. Almost invariably, schools established by communities aspire to complete Government takeover, while private yayasans often prefer partial Government support so they can maintain control. Schools established by teachers' associations often use public school facilities after hours and employ public school teachers as instructors. B. SECTOR ISSUES AND NATIONAL INITIATIVES 1.14 The project provinces face challenges in the provision of junior secondary education that are common to all provinces in Indonesia, though not to the same extent. These challenges are (a) to expand equitable access to junior secondary education; (b) to improve the quality of education throughout the provinces; and (c) to make education management more efficient as the provinces assume increased responsibility. Access is restricted mainly by the lack of places; high direct, transportation, and opportunity costs; and great distances and limited transportation networks in some provinces. In some instances parents in very remote or difficult areas do not express interest in junior secondary education as they think it is beyond their reach. The most important factors affecting quality and internal efficiency are: teacher knowledge and skills; the availability of textbooks, teaching materials, and equipment; the curriculum; pedagogical
 Staff Appraisal Report 5 supervision; the flexibility of the school calendar; school management; and examinations and educational assessment. 1.15 In spite of these constraints to access and quality, Indonesia has made great strides in gender equality in both primary and junior secondary education. Only slightly fewer girls than boys are enrolled in school at the national level, and the rates for three of the project provinces are higher than for Indonesia as a whole, and in the case of Central Java equal to the national average. Girls also have lower drop-out and repeater rates than boys and are often higher achievers. However, rural conditions similar to those which present obstacles to the development of junior secondary education also adversely affect the participation of girls in some communities. When schools are located a long way from villages, parents are less willing to let their daughters commute long distances for religious or cultural reasons, or undertake the costly expenditures of a long commute or relocation to urban areas. Consequently, boys in these communities get to go to school rather than girls or go to the better schools often located away from the remote villages. This happens particularly in certain remote areas of the Kalimantan provinces. 1.16 In addition to access and quality, all provinces face management challenges as a result of the deconcentration of tasks from the center to the provinces, a process this project will support. For historical and political reasons, public administration in Indonesia has been highly centralized and decision making is tightly controlled by central Government in Jakarta. The center has traditionally set objectives for education expansion and development, with few inputs from the provinces. However, the differences of local conditions in each province and district, accentuated by the great distances of the outer islands from the administrative center, make it increasingly difficult for central administration to devise and implement satisfactory solutions to local problems. Although Jakarta will retain a significant role in providing policy guidelines and promoting regional equity and overall economic development, the Government has decided gradually to devolve authority to the provinces and districts. This devolution will result in a deconcentration of the functions of the MOEC to provincial (Kanwil) and district (Kandep) education offices. Initiatives Related to Access 1.17 GOI is aware of these issues and a number of initiatives have been put in place to address them. To improve access, the policy of establishing a minimum size of nine classrooms for Government schools, which has prevented opening schools in small communities, is being changed to make it easier for schools with fewer classrooms to be built. Most rural areas also find it difficult to attract teachers, so the Government is planning to hire contract teachers for limited terms. 1.18 To make up for some of the inadequacies of the public sector, private schools supported by local communities, private educational foundations and religious groups have been established and account for about 40 percent of total enrollment at the junior secondary level. GOI supports these schools through a variety of measures, including provision of teachers, but compared to public schools, they are generally of lower quality and cost more to parents. The low quality in these schools is explained by poor quality teachers and even greater scarcity of educational
 6 Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project materials than in public schools. Unit costs of operations in these schools is, however, lower than in public schools. Current and proposed GOI support for private education would help maintain or increase its share of enrollment and improve quality. 1.19 In some sparsely populated areas some communities are not even large enough to support smaller schools; students have to travel over long distances or difficult terrain to get to school, so other alternatives are being implemented. The SMP Terbuka ("open SMP") program has been established to meet the needs of students who cannot attend regular schools because of distance or high direct and opportunity costs. These are non-fee-paying schools. and students attend afternoon classes run by secondary school teachers one or more times a week at a center, usually a junior secondary school, supplemented by tutorials in their villages. The effectiveness of these schools have been in question because of scarcity of learning materials and inadequate operational funds. As a result, student drop-out has been a serious problem in some areas. 1.20 To assist rural families who cannot afford to pay for education, GOI has established a scholarship program for children of low economic background and satisfactory academic achievement and personality. This program covers all costs related to junior secondary education; within the eligible group priority is given to children from remote areas, orphans, and girls. GOI plans to expand this program to improve its effectiveness. See Annex 10 for options to increase access to junior secondary education. Initiatives Related to Quality 1.21 Various initiatives have also been introduced to improve the quality of junior secondary education, including efforts to bring good teachers to underserved areas. Although there is an excess number of teachers in the aggregate, there is an unequal distribution of teachers between urban and rural areas within provinces because most rural teaching positions are considered undesirable. Soon after being appointed to rural areas, many teachers try to be placed into urban schools or find excuses to be absent for long periods. To address this issue of shortages of (particularly core subject) teachers in rural and remote areas, some provinces have experimented with hiring "contract teachers" in rural schools in core academic areas. Some rural communities have also provided their teachers with dormitories. In addition, the Government is already providing some financial compensation for service in hardship areas. Over the longer term, local recruitment is one practice that will help to keep teachers in rural areas. 1.22 The unequal distribution of teachers has rather different consequences in the urban areas where many teachers are underutilized, and where there is a perception of high levels of absenteeism. Financial rewards may not be the only answer. Teachers generally spend only a limited time in school because of the very few hours they are assigned to teach, the lack of teacher rooms, inadequate supplies of library, reference and teaching materials, and the absence of a structure which promotes interaction among teachers in schools. Management is therefore focused on purely administrative issues rather than the educational process. And the opportunity to promote improved teaching in the various subjects is lost. Commitment to outside activities is therefore sometimes greater than to teaching. Teachers recognize this gap and have effectively organized monthly subject teacher meetings as a part of their associations (MGMP) outside the school system. Similar groups are to be encouraged in schools, to help motivate teachers. These
 Staff Appraisal Report 7 groups would gradually be institutionalized as subject departments within which teachers would take collective responsibility for effective teaching of a given subject. This initiative, combined with efforts to reduce the over-supply of teachers and to provide teacher rooms and better libraries in schools, should increase teacher effectiveness. 1.23 Developed from an initiative taken by the MGMP teacher associations, an inservice teacher training program called PKG was introduced in 1983 to improve the subject-matter knowledge and skills of teachers (see Annex 11 for details). This program was highly successful in improving the pedagogical skills of teachers in the selected subject areas and created a positive attitude among teachers where it was provided. There were, however, some serious shortcomings of the program. The training curriculum did not fully address the subject-matter knowledge of teachers, development of skills in identifying learning difficulties was neglected, and teachers in rural areas could not be covered because of high costs and logistical difficulties. Training was provided every weekend followed by classroom visits, and trainees were supposed to develop their own materials. Some of the rural teachers who could be reached could not take full advantage of the program because of weak qualifications. The decentralization of the PKG and MGMP system to the district level and the systematic involvement of regional MOEC staff, including supervisors and principals in the training program, would help address this issue. 1.24 Providing incentives to teachers to spend more time on teaching and reduce absenteeism also needs to be considered. The costs of this can be high, however, as a general salary increase for all educational staff would have large fiscal implications on the overall civil service wage bill. Hence, specific teaching hour supplements that are phased in and linked to performance may be introduced if an efficient management system for this can be developed. 1.25 Efforts to provide schools with science equipment have not been completely successful. Procurement and distribution of equipment from Jakarta has resulted in difficult distribution problems and the supply of inappropriate equipment to schools. Changes in the provision of science equipment and other school materials are being piloted in the ongoing Second Secondary Education and Management Project (Loan 3158-IND), including requiring suppliers to distribute equipment directly to schools as part of their contracts. 1.26 The public examinations and testing system also has been improved under the Second Secondary Education and Management Project, but the process still needs to be completed. While preparation of test items for multiple-choice examinations have been greatly improved, development of open-ended and essay type questions still need to be addressed, and adequate mechanisms for objective scoring and analysis of results are only now being put in place. Through the same project, a national assessment system is being established to monitor the performance of the system regularly. Parallel with the development of the public system the quality of tests and identification of learning weaknesses in schools has also been initiated so that educational problems in individual schools can be addressed. A combination of the development of the public and private systems would provide teachers and managers with the required information for planning development of the system.

JUNIOR SECONDARY EDUCATION IN THE PROVINCES 1.27 The issues constraining further development of junior secondary education affect the four project provinces in significantly different ways, and they have developed their education strategies in response to local circumstances, needs, and opportunities. Central Java's developing economy can absorb a high rate of growth in junior secondary education but is constrained by rural conditions and a rate of poverty that is higher than the national average. The two Kalimantan provinces are held back by geography and poverty, but the need for expansion is less urgent, particularly in Central Kalimantan where opportunities for junior secondary school graduates are fewer and the pool of primary graduates is limited. Yogyakarta has already made substantial progress in expanding access to junior secondary education, so it is focusing its efforts on traditional and new measures to improve quality. Private schools have been remarkably successful in providing places for over 40 percent of students in three of the provinces, but at tremendous cost to parents. While Central Java has a relatively robust network of private schools in some areas, most such schools in rural Kalimantan are struggling to survive among poor, scattered villages, where the public sector's help is more crucial. In Central Kalimantan the role of the private sector is restricted (30 percent of enrollments) because conditions are less conducive for its development. Because of the diverse conditions in the project provinces, a variety of instruments would be used as appropriate to increase access and improve the quality of secondary education. Central Java 1.28 Socioeconomic Background. Central Java is densely populated, rural, and poor, but is changing rapidly. Although small in area, Central Java is the third largest province in Indonesia with about 30 million inhabitants. The population aged 13-15 peaked in 1993 at just over 2 million and is projected to continue declining throughout the project period. About 70 percent of the population lives in rural areas, compared to 78 percent in 1980. Central Java has 20 percent of the country's population living in poverty: over 7 million people had income levels below the
 Staff Appraisal Report 9 poverty line in 1990. The province is below the average for Indonesia in household income and per capita expenditure, and is the second lowest of the four project provinces. However, per capita GDP growth (6 percent) was higher than the Indonesian average (4.8 percent) from 1983- 1993. 1.29 The province's employed labor force is still concentrated in agriculture (40 percent in 1994), although the importance of the sector has fallen sharply (from 48 percent in 1987) as people shift into urban occupations. Urbanization and continued GDP growth have created a demand for increasing numbers of educated workers -- this is reflected in the wage premiums enjoyed by more educated wage earners. In 1992, employees with only primary education received an average monthly wage of about Rp 69,000, those with junior secondary education earned 27 percent more, those with senior secondary education earned 56 percent more than junior secondary education graduates, and those with tertiary education earned 52 percent more than senior secondary graduates. 1.30 Education System. Central Java enrolls 4.5 million primary school pupils in about 26,000 schools and accounts for 15 percent of the nation's primary enrollment. The province's gross enrollment rate is 114 percent at the primary level, compared to a junior secondary rate of 62 percent. The system enrolls 1.3 million junior secondary school students, compared to 340,000 in the other three provinces combined. As in all the project provinces, private schooling is crucial in helping to fill the gap between demand and supply. About 42 percent of the province's students attend private junior secondary schools, and there are twice as many private schools as public schools. Most of these private schools are small (about a third the size of the average public school) but relatively well-established, 80 percent having reached the "recognized" or "equivalent" level of accreditation. The private sector plays an even greater role at the senior secondary level, where it accounts for 60 percent of the total enrollment of 600,000 and 72 percent of the schools. The senior secondary gross enrollment rate in Central Java is 32 percent, slightly lower than the national rate. 1.31 Subsector Issues. The scale of Central Java's education system is enormous and presents the greatest challenges, in terms of absolute numbers, of any of the project provinces. Access to junior secondary education is highly variable throughout the province, based on income levels, and urban or rural living. Gross enrollment rates range from 42 percent to 109 percent by district. The rural enrollment rate is 46 percent compared to an urban rate of 77 percent. Of the 35 districts, eight account for half of the province's 13-15 age population not attending school. The provincial enrollment rate improved from 1992/93 to 1994/95 as junior secondary enrollment expanded even as the cohort population began to level off. Still, large numbers are not in school. A total of 775,000 youth of the appropriate age are not attending junior secondary school, and each year more than 160,000 pupils graduate from primary school but do not continue their studies. 1.32 Access is restricted in Central Java, particularly in rural areas, mainly because capacity is limited and because direct and opportunity costs are high. Public and private schools have expanded their enrollment rapidly to meet demand for school places, especially in cities and in other areas that are easy to reach. For example, private school enrollment increased by 26 percent over two years, 1992/93-1994/95. The number of students per classroom averages 46, so
 10 Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project specialized teaching classrooms such as laboratories and libraries often get used as regular classrooms to house the overflow of students. In addition, teachers favor urban schools while rural schools often do not have enough qualified staff. In rural low-income areas, many parents are hindered by high costs, even when places are available. Aside from the opportunity costs of sending children to school during working hours, rural households devote an exceptionally high share of their expenditure to junior secondary education, as noted earlier. Even in those rural areas where public transportation is available, the cost of a two-way trip every day contributes to these expenses and is probably prohibitive for low-income families. 1.33 The quality of education is also a concern, particularly in rural schools. Low quality reduces the interest of students and parents and leads to inefficiencies in the system as students score poorly on examinations, drop out, or repeat grades. Quality is particularly affected by the skills of teachers and the availability of instructional tools and facilities. Teachers need ongoing support and training because many are teaching with a weak educational background. Two-thirds of the province's SMP teachers do not have the required level of qualification, and 12 percent have no more than a secondary education (this rises to one third among Madrasah teachers). Only one teacher in five has received ongoing training and support under the current inservice program (PKG). Private schools tend to rely heavily on less-qualified part-time teachers. Whereas only 14 percent of the public school teachers are part-time, the ratio is 55 percent in private schools. 1.34 In addition, the facilities and teaching tools that teachers have to work with are limited. Among SMPs, which are generally better equipped than Madrasahs, 68 percent have little or no science teaching equipment. A third of the schools have no library, and many that do have few books. On average, school libraries have about two books per student; many of those are extra copies of textbooks and teacher handbooks, or are out of date and of poor quality. Textbooks for students have historically been limited, though this problem is being addressed through another Bank project. Because of the province's poverty, limited parental contributions also affect quality. Of family expenditure on junior secondary education, only 6 percent goes for textbooks, compared to a national average of 13 percent. 1.35 Broad Subsector Strategy. To respond to the likely rise in demand for junior secondary education in light of continuing industrial and urban development, GOI plans to aggressively support equitable expansion of junior secondary education in Central Java, although near- universal access cannot be achieved until a larger proportion of primary school pupils graduate from that level. Several types of support are planned. First, the province will build schools in and attract good teachers to areas of low enrollment, particularly larger rural settlements that the private sector is not covering. Second, it will further support the strong tradition of private schooling in this province by promoting quality improvement and more efficient administration, so parents will see it as providing education of a standard similar to that of public schools. Third, the province will alleviate financial constraints that keep the rural poor out of school, in part by reducing travel costs and by providing flexible education alternatives that do not force young people to choose between study and work. Fourth, improvement of the overall quality of education, particularly in rural areas, will increase the trainability of junior secondary school graduates from both public and private schools. Because of its large size and dense population, Central Java's strategies for implementing quality improvements would be different from those of the other provinces. For example, the inservice teacher training program strategy in the province
 Staff Appraisal Report 11 would focus on decentralization to the district level, and greater support would be given to MGMPs. Yogyakarta 1.36 Socioeconomic Background. Yogyakarta, small in land area, is the most heavily urbanized province in Indonesia, aside from Jakarta. Between 1980 and 1990, the urban population grew at a rate of 8 percent per annum. Still, over 40 percent of the people live in rural areas. Rapid urbanization has produced the lowest share of the labor force in agriculture (45 percent) among the four project provinces and the highest share in services (37 percent). Furthermore, social development indicators such as school attendance are among the highest in Indonesia. Yet GDP per capita is the lowest among the project provinces. High enrollment in junior secondary school is reflected in reduced wage premiums for educated workers. In 1992, the wage premium for workers with junior secondary education over those with primary education was only 11 percent, but that for senior secondary graduates over those with junior secondary education was 52 percent. 1.37 Education System. Yogyakarta has been remarkably successful in expanding the coverage of education. Of youth aged 10-19 years, 82 percent attend school and only 12 percent are working. Yogyakarta's primary school system has 355,000 pupils and a gross enrollment rate of 118 percent. About 80 percent of the primary schools are public, compared to 39 percent at the junior secondary level. A majority of junior secondary students, however, attend public schools rather than the smaller private schools. Yogyakarta and Jakarta are the two provinces that are farthest ahead of the national average in coverage at the lower secondary level. Yogyakarta's junior secondary system as a whole has a high gross enrollment rate of 89 percent. Most students attend general SMPs: out of a total of 547 junior secondary schools, the number of vocational schools in the province has dwindled to only three. Also, the role of Madrasahs, which are generally of lower quality than SMPs, is less significant here than in the other project provinces (they account for only 3 percent of all students). At the senior secondary level, the gross enrollment rate is an impressive 62 percent, compared to the national rate of 34 percent. The private system accounts for 76 percent of the senior secondary schools and 60 percent of the students. Yogyakarta has a strong tradition of education as reflected in its high gross enrollment rates even at the tertiary level - the highest in the country and more than three times the national average. 1.38 Subsector Issues. As a result of Yogyakarta's high population density, access to junior secondary schools is far less of a problem here than in the other project provinces. In Bantul and Gunung Kidul districts, which are rural, enrollment rates are lower, partly because of school costs and partly because some young people go to work or to school in the city. These districts account for two-thirds of the province's out-of-school youth in the 13-15 age group. The relative quality of the system is reflected in national examination scores, which are among the highest in the country. Interest in education is high, and the secondary school system has been supported through links with the tertiary institutions. The province as a whole, therefore, is aiming for excellence, although parts of Yogyakarta are still limited by weaknesses in teaching and by limited facilities and instructional tools. In general, Yogyakarta's private schools are relatively
 12 Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project well developed, particularly in comparison to those in the Kalimantan provinces. Over 90 percent have reached the accreditation level of "recognized" or "equivalent". 1.39 Broad Subsector Strategy. By continuing to target remaining pockets with lower school attendance, Yogyakarta can be expected to achieve near-universal junior secondary education from the current 89 percent within the next few years, without donor assistance. The province now concentrates on improving the quality of both junior and senior secondary education, which are already producing many well-performing graduates. The public and private school systems do this by setting and monitoring high standards, creating centers of excellence, trying new technologies, and training staff. Because of its achievements and small size, Yogyakarta is beginning to serve as a national model for testing the next generation of approaches in classroom instruction. As it does so, the province will develop mechanisms to evaluate the success of its innovations, share lessons learned with other provinces, and expand its participation in international comparisons of educational achievement. Yogyakarta will continue to support its private schools through training and the provision of other quality inputs. Central Kalimantan 1.40 Socioeconomic Background. Central Kalimantan has the smallest and most scattered population of the four provinces. Although it remains sparsely inhabited, the population is growing and becoming more urbanized. Four out of five people live in rural areas, but the urban population grew by an average of 10 percent a year from 1980-1990. Nine rivers provide the main transportation links between towns and villages. About 15 percent of the population lives in isolated villages of 100-200 people in remote mountainous and border areas, where travel is often extremely difficult. The indigenous Dayak groups of Central Kalimantan have traditionally practiced subsistence farming using slash-and-bum techniques. Transmigration largely from Java has brought plantation development and other changes to some rural areas. The Government has proposed to expand this program in the coming years, particularly in Kotawaringin Timur district. About 60 percent of the province's villages are classified by the Government as poor villages. 1.41 Employment in Central Kalimantan is concentrated in agriculture (65 percent) while manufacturing absorbs only 7 percent of the labor force. The province is rich in natural resources which are being exploited in enclave fashion. For this reason, GDP per capita is the highest among the four project provinces, though it grew more slowly (3 percent) than the national average during 1983-1993 and was not broadly distributed. Wage premiums for more highly educated workers are narrower than the average for Indonesia. The current structure of the economy has not begun to marginalize those workers with low educational qualification. 1.42 Education System. Primary schools in Central Kalimantan enroll 265,000 students for a gross enrollment rate of 108 percent, although many do not finish the full six years. At the junior secondary level, the gross enrollment rate is 50 percent, compared to the national rate of 58 percent. The system enrolls just 59,000 junior secondary school students (compared to over a million in Central Java), the smallest number of the four provinces. About 80 percent of those of junior secondary school age live in rural areas. The two districts of Kotawaringin Timur and Kapuas account for nearly three-quarters of the province's out-of-school youth of junior secondary school age. Public schools enroll about twice as many students as private schools not
 StaffAppraisal Report 13 only at the junior secondary level but also at the senior secondary level (unlike the Java provinces, where private schooling predominates at the senior level). The senior secondary gross enrollment rate (30 percent) is less than half Yogyakarta's rate. 1.43 Subsector Issues. Low population density in both Kalimantan provinces (for example, 11 persons per square kilometer in Central Kalimantan compared to over 900 in Yogyakarta) compounds the difficulty of providing access to secondary education, although the absolute number of out-of-school youth is relatively low. In addition, primary school retention and graduation rates are particularly low in this province, a weakness that limits the potential for junior secondary expansion. Many rural areas of Central Kalimantan are not easily reached, have populations that are too small for a regular SMP, and are in poor districts. As a result, the province's urban gross enrollment rate at the junior secondary level is nearly double the rural gross enrollment rate. This disparity is significantly more pronounced in both Kalimantan provinces than in the nation as a whole. Because the population is small and scattered, the average size of junior secondary schools here (I70) is less than half the average enrollment in high-density Central Java (357). Private schools have an average of only about 100 students each. Distance and the lack of accommodations prevent students in remote areas from attending school. 1.44 Costs also represent an access barrier, though many parents are willing to make significant sacrifices to send children to school. Despite the fact that household expenses at private schools are higher than in public schools, the number of private schools has increased over the past decade, though they enroll a smaller proportion of students here than in the other provinces. It is difficult to make private schools viable in many parts of Central Kalimantan because of the undeveloped formal economy and difficult terrain, and unlike West Kalimantan, there are fewer religious and other organizations involved. As a result, about 63 percent of private schools are relatively underdeveloped (in the lowest two categories of the private school classification). In addition to direct costs, opportunity costs are also high for students' families who rely on teenagers for agriculture, fishing, and household chores during normal school hours. Pockets of economic activity (such as gold mining) offer young people with less than a secondary school education some opportunities for wage employment. 1.45 The quality of schooling also suffers in the isolated, poor communities of the two Kalimantan provinces. In 1994/95, the average national exam scores in all the province's schools were moderate to poor; none was classified as good. Twenty percent of teachers in Central Kalimantan have only a secondary school education themselves. Isolation often cuts teachers off from further training or peer support. These teachers need ongoing training, upgrading, monitoring, and mentoring to strengthen their subject matter knowledge, pedagogical skills, and confidence in the classroom. But many of the province's teachers have not been covered by the PKG training program because of their isolation. In addition, the highest concentration of the teaching force is in urban areas where living conditions are better and adequate housing is available, while rural areas have an acute undersupply of qualified subject teachers. Due to the shortage of teachers, small rural junior secondary schools generally have multisubject teachers who are often not trained adequately in all subjects they teach, if in any. 1.46 In rural areas low quality of teaching is compounded by the widespread employment of part-time teachers, often poorly qualified and motivated. Increasing the challenge of teaching is
 14 Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project the shortage of appropriate teaching materials and facilities. Science is most often taught by lecture in regular classrooms with no teaching aids or equipment. Parents use only 3 percent of junior secondary schooling expenditure for textbooks. 1.47 Broad Subsector Strategy. Central Kalimantan will continue to expand junior secondary education, but the scale of the expansion will be relatively modest given the limited wage differentials between primary and secondary graduates and the small number and proportion of students completing the primary system. Because community-supported private schools are particularly weak in this province, the planned role of the public sector is crucial. First, Central Kalimantan will direct its investment at geographically isolated populations with low enrollment rates, where the province's limited private school system is not functioning. In these areas, the province will employ a range of options to reach potential students, such as building small schools to serve small communities, attracting teachers to underserved areas, supporting village- based schooling, and providing accommodation for students. Second, quality will be improved to increase the value of a junior secondary education, a development that would encourage students to complete the primary cycle and would help prepare students for further training as the province's natural resources are increasingly exploited. While maintaining quality in its own schools, the province will also support the relatively weak private sector so it can remain viable, particularly in remote areas. Third, the province will design its interventions to ease the financial burden of the poor. West Kalimantan 1.48 Socioeconomic Background. About a third of West Kalimantan's population was considered to be living in poverty in 1990, a high rate for Indonesia. However, the province is undergoing rapid economic and demographic change: GDP per capita grew by 6 percent annually 1983-1993, one of the highest rates in the country. The primary port city of Pontianak is a growing center for industry and regional trade. Traditionally, the province has relied on river transport, like Central Kalimantan. However, roads are becoming more important for the 79 percent of the population living in rural areas and have expanded the province's trade with bordering Sarawak (Malaysian Borneo). As a result of this growth, isolated families and entire villages are shifting from river areas to road areas to gain access to goods, services, and jobs. In addition, because of the province's low population density, GOI is resettling volunteer transmigrants from other parts of Indonesia in rural plantation areas (especially rubber and palm oil), where the soil is not fertile enough for growing rice. 1.49 West Kalimantan's economy remains heavily dependent on agriculture, and 68 percent of employed people were in that sector in 1993. But the nature of the agricultural activities (for example, the plantation crops) has put per capita incomes close to the average for Indonesia. In their turn, satisfactory average per capita income and higher economic growth rates have resulted in higher than average salaries for employed persons of all levels of education attainment, but especially at primary and junior secondary levels. A corollary of this is that wage premiums for educated workers are smaller than in other provinces (16 percent for junior secondary graduates and 5 percent for senior secondary graduates). However, many people in rural areas are largely outside the formal economy.
 StaffAppraisal Report 15 1.50 Education System. At the primary level, West Kalimantan has about 620,000 pupils in 3,870 schools, 90 percent of which are public. The primary gross enrollment rate is 111 percent. The secondary school enrollment rates are the lowest of the four project provinces. At the junior secondary level, the gross enrollment rate is 46 percent, compared to the national rate of 58 percent. The junior secondary system enrolls 122,000 students, about 51,000 of them in private schools. The proportion of schools that are public or private Madrasahs has doubled over the past decade. Schools in plantation areas adjacent to indigenous Dayak communities sometimes serve a mixture of ethnic and religious groups. In fact, unlike the other project provinces, where most SMP students are Islamic, SMP students in West Kalimantan are as likely to be either Christian or Buddhist as Muslim. At the senior secondary level, the gross enrollment ratio is 24 percent (compared to the national rate of 34 percent). Although public schools account for just over a quarter of the total number of senior secondary schools in the province, they enroll as many students as private schools. 1.51 Subsector Issues. As in other parts of Kalimantan, access to education is restricted by distance and cost. As a result, the rural enrollment rate in West Kalimantan is less than a third of the enrollment rate in urban areas; in contrast, nationally the rural rate is more than half the urban rate. Although the most populated districts near the coastal road and river networks account for the majority of the province's youth who are not in junior secondary school, the more remote and sparsely populated districts (such as Sintang, Sanggau, and Ketapang) have lower enrollment rates. Much of the population lives in small villages scattered over difficult terrain that have an insufficient number of young people to justify a separate school of typical size. Transportation to the nearest school is often a great distance by foot or by river, and flooding during the rainy season isolates villages from each other. Schools in such areas also find it difficult to attract good teachers because of harsh local conditions. 1.52 If they have a school at all, remote villages are often served by a small private school. The average size of junior secondary schools in the province as a whole (191) is smaller here than in the Java provinces. A large number of rural private schools have been established by communities, with limited resources, as a last resort. However, many of them are weak: 80 percent of all private schools have not advanced in their accreditation beyond the basic "registered" status. In some villages, Madrasahs open where the public sector has not reached. They are more acceptable than public schools to many Muslim parents of females, partly because of their religious instruction and partly because of their proximity to the village. However, the costs of private Madrasahs and other schools is more than many can afford. In addition to high direct costs relative to rural incomes, opportunity costs in certain areas limit enrollment. Young people in certain subdistricts can find forestry jobs or work in home industries, and many are needed to help their parents at home or in economic activities such as fishing or farming during morning school hours. 1.53 The qusality of the small, private schools that are common in remote areas is often low. National examination (NEM) scores for the province declined between 1992/93 and 1994/95 and were especially weak in science, mathematics, and English. Private school teachers are generally less qualified than their public school counterparts: more than half have no more than a senior secondary school education. Of all teachers, in both public and private schools, only 11 percent have the newly required qualification of DIII degree, and about 30 percent even have no training
 16 Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project beyond secondary school. Because of their isolation, many receive limited or no inservice training or onservice support. The relatively high costs met by families affect not only access but quality. After paying the necessary registration fees and other costs needed to establish a school or enroll their children, parents and school associations often cannot afford significant amounts to ensure students get a quality education. For example, families spend more than three times as much for school uniforms as for textbooks. 1.54 Broad Subsector Strategy. Junior secondary education in this province will be developed at a moderate pace to help the province manage and take advantage of demographic and economic change. The province will give special attention to expanding education for the majority of the rural population who are unlikely to benefit substantially from rapid change unless they are better educated. This agenda will be supported in several ways. First, while addressing barriers of geography and distance by placing small schools in remote areas, the province will also take advantage of village consolidation and improved transportation networks by placing somewhat larger schools in more densely populated areas. Public schools will be placed in such rural settlements where private schools have not developed, either because of isolation or low regional incomes. Stronger private schools, including religious schools, will be allowed to grow without competition from the public sector. Second, quality will be addressed urgently, particularly in rural schools that have difficulty training unqualified teachers and keeping good ones. Relatively weak community-supported schools, in particular, will be given special consideration. Third, the province's expansion efforts will be designed to keep the cost of education reasonable for the high number of people living in poverty.

GOVERNMENT STRATEGY 2.1 As part of the Repelita VI (1994/99) program, the Government set the important goal of extending access to high quality junior secondary education. This objective is integral to the goal of attaining universal coverage of nine years of basic education by the end of Repelita VIII (2008/09). To support this ambitious goal, the Government has adopted several policy measures and strategies (see Annex 9): (a) it plans to provide additional resources to basic education, starting with an increase of 20 percent in the overall budget of education for the 1996/97 fiscal year; (b) it has abolished junior secondary school fees and admission requirements for primary school graduates; (c) it is providing free textbooks for all primary and junior secondary schoolchildren; (d) it is supporting private junior secondary schools with public teachers and other inputs to maintain and even increase their significant enrollment participation at this school level; (e) it continues to upgrade teachers' skills for both public and private schools through inservice programs; (f) it has started the construction or development of regular or alternative schools in rural and remote villages; (g) it has phased out all diploma courses for the preservice education of secondary school teachers (junior and senior) so all new teachers at that level now need to have an SI (undergraduate degree); (h) it is upgrading existing junior secondary school teachers to DII (two-year post-secondary diploma) at public expense; and (i) it is extending subsidies (scholarships) to capable but poor students to begin or continue junior secondary education. B. LESSONS LEARNED 2.2 Integration of the following lessons from previous Bank projects would help build on the exceptional performance of the Bank in the education sector in Indonesia. All the 21 previous projects have been judged satisfactory by OED, and they have set the stage for the more challenging tasks in this sector. OED Document No. 9752, Indonesian Education and the World Bank: an Assessment of Two Decades of Lending (1991) found that support for education projects was timely and that the Bank gave valuable advice to the Government. Although the projects were successful, there is a continuing need to improve the quality of education and to strengthen management at the provincial level, particularly in light of the current trend of deconcentrating responsibilities, a process this project will support. 2.3 OED Report. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.1 The project would assist the MOEC in addressing the quality and coverage of junior secondary education in the provinces of Central Java, Yogyakarta, Central Kalimantan, and West Kalimantan. PROJECT DESCRIPTION Project Components 3.3 To meet the objectives of increasing access to junior secondary education, improving the quality of secondary education, and enhancing education management, activities related to the following components and subcomponents would be implemented selectively and in varying degrees in the public and private systems of the four project provinces.  StaffAppraisal Report 23 3.4 Expand Access (estimated base costs of $60.3 million). To improve access to junior secondary education, the project would (a) create a total of 45,000 school places by building regular and small junior secondary schools in underserved rural areas; (b) gradually expand alternative equivalency programs by creating 11,000 places with greater quality inputs for those who cannot attend regular schools, and monitor the programs' effectiveness; (c) assist in community construction of student and teacher accommodations for public and private schools in isolated areas; (d) provide contract teachers for rural areas; (e) finance scholarships for 34,000 poor students who perform well, with priority given to girls in public and private schools; and (f) provide parents with information about how to take full advantage of the benefits of junior secondary schooling in their local areas. PROJECT ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 3.31 The economic analysis conducted for the project consisted of: (a) analysis of educational demand and the rationale for public investment in junior secondary education; (b) fiscal analysis; (c) review of alternatives; and (d) cost-benefit analysis. Details are provided in Annex 7. 3.32 There are both efficiency and equity grounds for additional public intervention in junior secondary education in Indonesia today. It is primarily the poor and near-poor (and mostly those in rural areas) who are not enrolling in school and whose participation declined in the late 1980s to early 1990s. One of the primary factors explaining the low demand during that period is the high direct costs of education. A second factor is indirect (opportunity) costs which exacerbated the effect of high direct costs. Coupled with stagnant real wages in the 1980s and the effects of cuts in public expenditure on basic education in the mid-1980s (school construction came to a virtual halt), these factors contributed to faltering demand. The past two years have seen the reversal of these trends as enrollment rates have risen significantly in all provinces. 3.33 Since investment in junior secondary education is desirable on both efficiency and equity grounds, the key questions for the Government are the budgetary implications of the expansion and how to expand the system. The budgetary implications of the expansion are sizable ($7.6 billion; see Annex 7 and para. 1.9), but estimation shows that the policy is attainable if the economy continues to grow at the rate attained in recent decades, additional funds are made available to junior secondary including external borrowing (para. 1.9), and the private sector retains its current significant share. 3.34 Analysis of alternatives considered the role of the private sector in the expansion program and the fiscal implications of mainly public expansion versus one which made room for private expansion at the current rate of 40 percent of enrollments in private schools. The budgetary implications double in the first scenario ($14.5 billion compared to $7.6 billion). There are additional merits to preserving the private sector. First, given the current and projected surplus of teachers, a robust private sector is an effective means for helping to clear the market for teachers. Second, Madrasah schools (religious schools which currently enroll about 20 percent of junior secondary students) offer access to junior secondary in small, poor communities and at a cost that is significantly lower than even MOEC-supervised private schools. These schools also enroll a higher proportion of girls than boys, reflecting the preference pattern of some families for non-secular education. Third, maintaining the share of private schools at the junior secondary level establishes the basis for sustaining the even larger share of private schools at the senior secondary level (54 percent of enrollments in 1993/94).
 StaffAppraisal Report 31 3.35 Beyond the public/private alternatives, the Government has experimented with alternative modes of delivering junior secondary education (in respect of the regular SMP model). These include SMP Kecil and SMP Terbuka. While not entirely substitutes for each other (or to the regular SMPs), and experimentation to improve their quality is still ongoing, preliminary unit cost comparisons indicate that gains can be achieved by utilizing these less costly alternative models of junior secondary education in rural and remote areas. 3.36 The economic rate of return for the project investment is estimated by province and component (increasing access and enhancing quality, but excluding the management component). The estimates are obtained by solving for the internal rate of return that equates a stream of benefits and costs resulting from the investment over a thirty year horizon. The benefits of the projects are derived from the increased numbers of students enrolled in junior secondary in any given year, but also include the additional stream of students expected to proceed to senior secondary and tertiary education. A monetary value of the benefits of each stream of beneficiaries is estimated using the difference in wages between one level of education and the next. Benefits will also accrue from investments in enhancing the quality of junior secondary. A benchmark assumption of a 15 percent additional wage premium earned by a higher quality graduate is made. No additional building of school places will be carried out by project. 3.37 Simulations were run varying some of the underlying assumptions. In all, the main variables to which the system appears to be most sensitive to are those affecting quality. This is not surprising given the large numbers of beneficiaries which are impacted by this investment. Impact on Women 3.39 Enrollment figures by province reveal no great disparities between male and female participation in junior secondary education in the four project provinces. With respect to bid methodology, the planning directorate in Jakarta (Bappenas) keeps and publicizes an annually updated list of reference prices for the m2 construction of different types of construction in each district (kabupaten). Because the bidding documents spell out the number of square meters to be constructed and the unit costs (per m2) are known, the bidding is done against a known reference price. With respect to bid evaluation, only those bids that are in the "brackets" between the reference price plus 10 percent (top), and 90 percent of the reference price (bottom) are considered to be responsive bids. Other bids are rejected as non-responsive. The economic analysis first aims to understand the determinants of demand for junior secondary education in Indonesia particularly since there have been variations in the past decade and there are significant disparities among socio-economic groups (Section I). This section establishes that the main determinants of demand are household incomes, costs of schooling and distance to school; the latter two are variables that Government can affect through this project. Therationale for additional public investment in junior secondary is investigated subsequently (Section I), and it is argued that on both efficiency and equity grounds, there are justifications for additional public intervention in expanding junior secondary. The cost implications of the Government's expansion program (Section II) are then considered. A key element is the future role of the private sector in the provision of junior secondary education. The conclusions reached are that a sizable budgetary effort will be required, but that the policy is attainable if the economy continues to grow at its historical rate, additional funds are made available to junior secondary including external borrowing and the private sector retains its current large share. The next question that arises is how best to provide junior secondary education. The Government has at its reach both demand and supply policy instruments and within the latter several alternative modes of junior secondary exist. These are analyzed in Section III. Finally, the costs and benefits of the specific project design are laid out and an economic rate of return is calculated (Section IV). The financial impact of the project on the provincial budgets and prospects of sustainability is analyzed in Section II. I. DEMAND ANALYSIS AND RATIONALE FOR PUBLIC INVESTMENT IN JUNIOR SECONDARY Enrollment at the junior secondary level expanded rapidly between the late 1960's and 1980's, reaching 63 percent in gross terms in 1988 (47 percent NER).' For the next five years, however, enrollment fell to 52 percent (41 percent NER) by 1993 (declining in absolute terms from 7.8 million to 7.1 million students). There remain significant differences in enrollments, however, among income groups and urban-rural residents. In 1994, the net enrollment rate among the top quintile was 66 percent compared to 25 percent for the lowest quintile.2 Significant differences also exist among urban and rural enrollment rates: 62 percent of urban children aged 13-15 years old are in junior secondary, compared to 33 percent of rural children. When decomposed by income and urban-rural levels, enrollments are low for the poor and near-poor children in both rural and urban areas, and the middle income rural children.3 High direct costs are one oQL the primary factors explaining the low junior secondary enrollment rates among the poor and near-poor. Overall, the cost to families of educating a child in junior secondary comes to an annual average of Rp210,000 (1994). This is more than two-and-a-half times the cost of primary education (an average Rp8O,000).4 For households in the lowest quintile, total expenditure per junior secondary student is equivalent to approximately 80 percent of per capita household expenditure. Particularly significant are the up-front registration (entrance) fees that parents must pay: in 1994, the average entrance fee for junior secondary was Rp47,500, which for those in the two lower quintiles was five times more than the registration fee paid for primary education. Indirect (opportunity) costs of junior secondary education are significant in rural areas. and this exacerbates the effect of high direct costs especially among the poor. Schools are in short supply in rural areas which imposes high travel time and costs. The longer the travel time, the higher the opportunity cost of schooling, and the more reluctant parents will be to send their children to school. Though the difference between average travel time to primary school for urban versus rural residents is insignificant, the national average travel time to junior secondary schools in rural areas is 50 percent higher than in urban areas.5 Earnings foregone while attending school can also be significant among the poor. Parents' decisions to send a child to junior secondary education depends on the aforementioned costs and also on: I) income constraints and credit markets failure. The poor have not only low income but also greater difficulty to borrow. Particularly in the area of human capital investments, the possibility of borrowing is practically non-existent even among better off families.  90 Annex IO: Page 1 of 4 INDONESIA Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project OPTIONS FOR INCREASING ACCESS To increase access to junior secondary education, a variety of strategies will be employed according to their appropriateness in each of the provinces, including activities to: (a) increase the number of places in public schools in order to meet demand; (b) provide cost- effective alternative solutions besides traditional schools in targeted areas; (c) support low- income junior secondary students through scholarships; and (d) other strategies to increase access including the provision of accommodation at existing schools for students who live too far to travel. Increasing Places in Public Schools. To increase the opportunities for junior secondary education, building or expanding traditional junior secondary schools as well as developing the small SMP, or SMP Kecil, are the first options. Each of these options will be appropriate and cost-effective only in certain circumstances and will be introduced when compatible with local conditions in each of the provinces, as determined by specific criteria drawn up by each province. Regular SMP and SMP Kecil. Standard building designs for regular SMPs call for 9, 18, or 27 classrooms. In densely populated areas, regular SMPs remain the obvious solution to increase access. However, schools of standard size are too large to serve rural areas with small, scattered populations, which nevertheless have sufficient cohort populations to justify a new small school. To increase access in these areas, the Government plans to use the SMP Kecil, which has fewer than nine classrooms. There would be fewer teachers than the usual requirement (at least five subject teachers for this type of schools). The main advantage of the SMP Kecil is that it would allow the services of traditional schools to be provided to underserved areas with small numbers of potential students. In some situations, SMP Kecils are an appropriate and cost-effective option for expanding education. General criteria used by the provinces for the establishment of an SMP Kecil include: (a) a number of local feeder schools would ensure a minimum of about 30 graduates per year; (b) except for those students provided with dormitories, the maximum distance for students to reach the school should be 5 kilometers or, alternatively, a one-hour trip; (c) the school should guarantee the availability of at least three teachers, with qualifications among them to teach math, science, Bahasa Indonesia, social sciences, local content, and English; (d) rural, remote and poor areas are given priority; (e) priority is given to kabupaten and kecamatan with the lowest gross enrollment or transition rates; and (f) schools should not be in areas served by an existing public or private school. Once the decision is made, teachers would be offered added incentives to teach in isolated areas (e.g., accommodation where appropriate) and education authorities would provide a minimum set of teaching aids. An attachment shows the criteria for school location.
 Annex 10: Page 2 of 4 91 Education for Difficult Areas. Some areas have an insufficient number of feeder primary students within a reasonable distance, or a large number of young people who are not able to attend school at normal times for work-related reasons. In other instances, youth do not attend school because parents cannot afford to pay for school expenses. The expansion of access by means of regular schools will not catch these potential students. Flexible, community-based schooling that requires no separate infrastructure development is often part of the solution. At present the Government offers programs, parallel to regular secondary education, such as the SMP Terbuka program (open secondary schooling). SMP Terbuka programs do not charge fees to students. Criteria for applying these programs are similar to the ones for the SMP Kecils in terms of walking distance. A minimal class size of about a dozen students would suffice. These programs would target the rural population in distant areas, where the establishment of a "small" school is not feasible, and would represent the minimum educational service that education authorities needs to provide to these areas. SMP Terbuka. The SMP Terbuka program, now in operation for only the second year, is conceived as a major alternative for school-age children who fail to enter a regular public school because of financial difficulties in entering a public or private school, low grades in the end-of-level Ebtanas examinations, and/or lack of facilities in the area. Students in Terbuka programs are free only at certain times of the day, often in the mornings - most of them help their parents in farming, fishing, or home chores. In most cases, students attend classes in a regular SMP in the afternoons once or twice a week (a total of three to four hours), with teachers from the "mother" SMP school. Four or five other afternoons in the week, students do their home assignment, using specially prepared modules, in a learning post in the village under the supervision of a tutor. Such alternative programs as SMP Terbuka meet a need in deprived areas: they do not involve high costs for parents (practically only transportation), are flexible in the timing, and do reach a certain percentage of out-of-school youngsters. The main weaknesses are (a) the often low qualifications and competence of tutors; (b) the relatively high costs of transportation, which adversely affect attendance in some cases; (c) the qualifications of students attending these programs, many of whom are bound to be those with low achievement in primary schools; (d) a shortage of student modules; and (e) reduced class attendance and contact with qualified teachers compared to regular SMP. Some parents recognize these weaknesses and reject SMP Terbuka because it is not a "regular" school. To improve the quality and effectiveness of the program: (a) tutors would be given intensive training (at present Terbuka tutors attend only a 5-day training course, which appears inadequate); (b) village chiefs, parents, and community members would be sensitized and mobilized to ensure that students do attend tutorial classes regularly; (c) transportation costs in particularly difficult or remote areas would be subsidized by the Government; and (d) consideration should be given to increasing the length of the program; (e) students will be required to pass the Ebtanas final examination like other regular SMP students; (f) Government is considering providing subsidies to students with good learning achievements to compensate for direct and opportunity costs. The effectiveness of the Terbuka program will be evaluated during the project.

Families in the lower income deciles bear large financial burdens when their children attend junior secondary school, relative to the total monthly family expenditures (between 40% and 80%). These costs include school registration fees, tuition, parental contributions, expenses for unifroms, transport, books and other costs. Furthermore, children from poor families attending school incur additional costs in the form of foregone income they could earn within or outside the household. Simulations, based on econometric modeling indicate that abolishing school fees would raise the transition rate from primary schools to junior secondary by 12%; subsidizing all school-related direct costs would raise the rate by 32%, primarily bringing into school those children, whose parents value education, but cannot afford to pay. GOI is currently operating a nationwide scholarship program covering some 27,000 junior secondary students. The scholarship consists of financial support amounting to Rp 25,000 per month for nine months, an ample amount to cover all school-related costs. A new fund distribution mechanism has recently been implemented, with funds being distributed through the post office. The fund provides scholarships to children of low economic background and satisfactory academic achievement and personality. Within these criteria, preference is given to children from remote areas, orphans and girls. The fund is operating well, and though very limited, is much appreciated. It is proposed in the project, to expand the scholarship program to cover a much larger target group, to make a greater impact in bringing poor children into SLTP. The current program would be augmented, with adaptations as follows: (a) scholarships would be provided to 12,200 students for Central Java, 1,700 for Yogyakarta, 1,160 for Central Kalimantan, and 2,100 for West Kalimantan; (b) unit costs would be set at Rp 25,000 average per student per year; and (c) a simple monitoring mechanism will be implemented to make sure that funds reach the recipients intact and that selection criteria are followed. By project mid-term review, the entire program will be evaluated for impact. An attachment to this Annex contains details of the criteria for award and monitoring the program. Other Strategies to Increase Access. In addition to these strategies to increase access by expanding the number of places in junior secondary education, the Government has proposed other measures including supporting community construction of student dormitories to increase opportunities for dispersed populations in rural areas. In many such areas, students have already built, on their own, temporary accommodation, often of poor quality and often beyond the financial resources of parents. The project would support their efforts. Dormitories would be located according to priority in areas with low enrollment rates, where such accommodation is culturally acceptable. The lack of teachers in such areas is also a problem, and quality expansion relies on attracting and retaining adequately trained staff. Options include increasing the number of teachers in underserved areas through redeployment and support for the construction of teacher accommodation. In many rural areas, there is no accommodation provided and none to be rented. In some cases, communities have built teacher "messes", or small flats, especially for single teachers. Such efforts could be encouraged and supported through funds for materials and technical assistance to needy communities that are willing and able to carry
