 Annex II: Page I of 6 99 INDONESIA Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project INSERVICE TEACHER TRAINING STRATEGY Introduction The PKG Program. The Directorate of General Secondary Education (Dikmenum) began programs to strengthen the quality of secondary education more than 20 years ago, but the main initiative has been the Pemantapan Kerja Guru (PKG) program, which started working with science teachers in 1980. The program was extended to cover teachers of four other major subjects (mathematics, English, Bahasa Indonesia and geography) during the 1980s. For its first five years, PKG was supported by a UNDP/UNESCO grant, but since 1984 activities have been funded through two joint Government of Indonesia/World Bank projects (the First and Second Secondary Education and Management Projects). Two major characteristics defined PKG training: * Inservice instruction at the training center was supported by follow-up visits to participants' schools (onservice training); * Teacher educators from the Teacher Training Institutions (IKIPS and FKIPs) made a substantial contribution to subject-content learning; but responsibility for the practical aspects of the training program, including the onservice visits, was in the hands of experienced teachers (instructors). Before starting PKG work, new instructors received specially-designed short courses in Malaysia, Singapore, the United Kingdom, or Australia. Subsequently, selected instructors undertook more extended courses overseas; and more than 80 of them now hold masters' degrees in pedagogy of their teaching subject. Originally, all PKG training was delivered through a single model, sometimes referred to as PKG (murni) pure. A PKG murni training cycle ran for 16 weeks, during which participants (i) received two two-week blocks of inservice training, at a provincial center; (ii) took part in approximately 12 weekly meetings; and (iii) received three onservice visits at their schools. The main focus during the inservice blocks was on subject content, during the weekly meetings, on lesson planning and feedback; and during the onservice visits, on practical application in the classroom. Sanggar PKG. During the mid-1980s, a second less-intensive model was introduced to disseminate PKG approaches more rapidly, and to reduce costs. The combination of inservicing and onservicing was maintained, but the residential block courses were dropped, and the program for the weekly meetings restructured to include subject content as well as lesson planning and follow-up. Sanggar PKG training was carried out by guru inti (key teachers). Originally the guru inti were simply teachers who had performed well in PKG
 100 Annex 11. Page 2 of 6 murni training, but starting in 1990, a special training program was set up for them (Latihan Kerja Guru Inti: LKGI). In the long-established subjects (science, mathematics, English) LKGI training replaced the original PKG mumi program, which was discontinued at this time. The instructors thus became trainers of trainers rather than trainers of teachers. MGMP Training. In 1993 Sanggar PKG was in turn replaced by a new program, Musyawara Guru Mata Pelajaran (MGMP), which continues to the present. Training content remains much the same, but intensity is further reduced. Teachers' meetings take place on average once every three weeks, and onservice visits have been dropped altogether. The two- week training programs for guru inti (LKGI) have been curtailed to two days only. PKG Model C Training. The kabupaten-based Sanggar PKG program, and the successor MGMP program, extended training activities to teachers in the more-accessible rural schools, but were not able to reach teachers in the most isolated schools. PKG Model C was initiated in 1993 to meet the needs of these teachers. The program is run at the provincial level, by instructors rather than guru inti. Participants attend two block inservice courses of two weeks each, and receive a single onservice visit. There are no weekly meetings. Evaluation Studies The 1984 UNDPIUNESCO PKG Science Evaluation. This was a full-scale evaluation of a PKG program, involving classroom observation and pupil assessment. based on observations of lessons taught by more than 500 teachers, and the assessment of the performance of a similar number of student groups in science experiments, the evaluators concluded that PKG science had produced an impressive impact, both on the teaching behavior of teachers and on the learning behavior of pupils. PKG-trained teachers asked more questions - particularly high intellectual demand questions - and a higher proportion of their questions were answered by the pupils. In the science experiments, pupil groups whose teachers had had a high level of exposure to PKG scored, in some cases, more than two standard deviations better than groups whose teachers had had no PKG exposure. The review carried out for project preparation was done over a limited time period: one week in Jakarta, followed by two weeks fieldwork in the provinces using the flexible method of rapid policy appraisal. The review covered three provinces, selected from among those to be included in the proposed Secondary Education Projects: D.I. Aceh, Jawa Timur, and Kalimantan Barat. In each province, three schools were visited: first, a school in or near the kabupaten capital, selected by the PKG team as a model of good practice; second, a school in a moderately accessible rural area; and third, a school in a remote area, if possible, one participating in the Model C program.
 Annex 11: Page 3 of 6 101 Findings The results of the review can be summarized in three main findings: (a) The programs have succeeded in developing an extensive group of secondary school teachers into teacher trainers, widely distributed throughout the Republic at both the provincial and the kabupaten level (instructors and guru inti, respectively). The quality of these trainers is variable, but the best of them are highly impressive. They constitute an invaluable human resource which should be fully utilized in future quality-improvement activities. (b) There was excellent teaching in a few schools, mainly located in or near major city centers where exposure to PKG has been greatest. Elsewhere, however, evidence of improved pedagogy in the classroom was not evident. The problems were of at least three major kinds: (a) Delivery problems. During the pilot phase of PKG, while the project was limited in scope, the core group of trainers (the instructors) were able to work directly with the end-users (the teachers). But as coverage widened, it was necessary to introduce intermediate trainers (the guru inti), who transmitted the messages from the core group to the end users. These intermediate trainers were, inevitably, not as well prepared as the core group. In consequence, the flow of new ideas tended to become restricted - even, in some cases, to dry up altogether. (b) Management problems. As a pilot project, PKG was run effectively by a small team of innovators on the basis of enthusiasm, charisma, and personal contacts. But as activities expanded, the lack of formal linkages to the routine management system became a constraint on success. (c) Financial problems. On a per capita basis, the pilot program was generously funded, but as the number of participants multiplied, financing became more of a constraint. Three other problems, not connected with the expanding scope of the program, have also tended to restrict the effectiveness of PKG: (a) Course content. From a limited observation of MGMP and Model C training courses, it seems that while a great deal of effort is put into activities which strengthen the teacher, relatively little attention is paid to student learning.

The TAT will focus its analysis on how student assessment is conducted in classroom, data reported to provincial level, and feedback provided back to schools and classrooms for the benefit of each teacher and the corresponding students. With regard to examinations the TAT will evaluate the effectiveness of improvements in the preparation, administration, scoring and reporting of examination results at the school, district and province levels and the impact of this on student learning.

For each province, the TAT will verify that schools, and dormitories for students and teachers built under the project were consistent with the agreed criteria for site selection. Adequacy of these constructions should be the object of observation and dialogue with teachers, students and communities. Three- and six-classroom schools in the rural areas constitute an innovation that deserves careful assessment by the TAT. 12. Scholarship Program. The team will verify in their visits to schools that students were awarded scholarships under the program according to agreed criteria and conditions, and particularly the wide advertisement of the awarding processes. This will be done through a review of sample award documents, documentation related to the flow of information among concerned parties, and a spot check of recipients to ensure that the full scholarship is actually received and used as intended. 13. Science Education Study. The TAT will evaluate the utility of the different packages of equipment provided to the different categories of schools with respect to their contribution to improvements in science teaching, cost, and ease of use, maintenance and replacement. 14. Management Practices and Changes. The TAT will ensure that the proper staff are receiving the technical and managerial training at provincial, district, and school levels, and that trained staff receive posting consistent with their newly acquired skills. It will also ensure that equipment provided under the project is actually used as intended. Contract and Assistance 15. A contract will be signed between the Central Program Coordination Unit (CPCU) at Dikmenum and the selected audit team for a month a year starting in 1997. The CPCU will be responsible for TAT's schedule and follow-up. In the provinces the two PPIUs will provide the assistance required for a timely and adequate schedule of visits and contacts, including remote project areas. Duration and Expected Product 16. The TAT will survey implementation's progress in the second, third and fourth years of the project, and each survey is expected to be realized in a month. The TAT will provide its report to the CPCU, the PPIUs and the World Bank for review and comments before issuing a final document. The TAT will also ensure that implementation of recommendations issued by CPCU or the Bank after analysis of the progress reports are actually implemented in the following year. The first audit shall not start before 18 months after the project started.

doc.abstracts: The Central Indonesia Junior Secondary Education Project will assist the Ministry of Education and Culture in addressing the quality and coverage of junior secondary education in the provinces of Central Java, Yogyakarta, Central Kalimantan, and West Kalimantan. The project's objectives are to: 1) expand access to junior education in a cost-effective and equitable way; 2) improve the quality of junior and senior secondary education; and 3) strengthen the management of the education system at all levels. The project components are as follows: 1) expansion of access which will include new schools, alternative equivalency programs, student scholarships, student and teacher accommodation, social marketing, and contract teachers; 2) quality enhancement consisting of teacher training, tools for effective teaching, student performance assessment, and special initiatives; 3) strengthening of education management involving forecasting, planning and monitoring, secondary education information system, school to Kandep/Kanwil information, information technology support, and school management; and 4) project management support.
